statements.statement: As someone who cares about keeping our community clean and welcoming, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility, clear rules, and real consequences. We should have plenty of trash and recycling bins, visible signage, and strict enforcement of fines for those who litter, paired with community clean-up events and education in schools and churches. When people see their neighbors and local businesses taking pride in shared spaces, they’re more likely to do their part instead of expecting the government to solve everything.

statements.statement: La basura en las calles es, ante todo, un problema de educación y respeto, no de falta de leyes. Ya tenemos suficientes normas; lo que hace falta es hacerlas cumplir de verdad con multas altas, cámaras en puntos críticos y que la gente vea consecuencias claras por tirar basura. También creo que las escuelas y las iglesias deberían enseñar más sobre responsabilidad personal y cuidado del vecindario, porque si uno respeta el lugar donde vive, no lo ensucia. El gobierno local puede poner más botes de basura, sí, pero sin disciplina y valores, nada de eso funciona.

statements.statement: Working in a hospital, I see every day how a clean environment directly impacts people’s health, so I believe strong anti-littering policies are essential. We should combine clear rules and meaningful fines with plenty of trash and recycling bins, public education (especially in schools), and community clean-up programs so families and kids learn to take pride in their neighborhoods.

statements.statement: As someone who spends my days moving goods around massive warehouse spaces, I know firsthand how much cleaner and safer a place is when everyone takes responsibility for what they leave behind. I think the best way to prevent littering in public spaces is a mix of strict enforcement with real fines, plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, and city-funded cleanup jobs that pay people a fair wage. We should also invest in public education, especially in schools and churches, to make taking care of shared spaces a basic community value, not just a rule you follow when someone’s watching.

statements.statement: If you want to cut down on littering, you need clear rules, visible enforcement, and real consequences. I spent a career seeing how small signs of disorder invite bigger problems, so ticketing people who litter, putting up more trash cans, and having officers or city workers actually patrol and follow through would make a difference. Public service announcements are fine, but without accountability and a basic standard of respect for shared spaces, they don’t go far enough.

statements.statement: As someone who spends a lot of time out in parks, festivals, and city streets, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of smart infrastructure and real accountability. Cities should provide plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, invest in public education campaigns that appeal to community pride and environmental responsibility, and back that up with meaningful fines for people who still litter. I’d also love to see more community clean-up events and partnerships with local businesses and venues, so keeping public spaces clean feels like a shared, social effort rather than just a rule imposed from above.

statements.statement: As someone who spends a lot of time in parks and community spaces with my family, I think preventing littering starts with a mix of personal responsibility, education, and practical infrastructure. We need plenty of visible trash and recycling bins, consistent enforcement of fines for littering, and community-based efforts—like school programs and local cleanup days—that teach kids and adults alike to take pride in keeping shared spaces clean.

statements.statement: As someone who loves walking to local theaters and painting outdoor scenes, it breaks my heart to see trash scattered across parks and sidewalks. We need stronger public investment in frequent trash and recycling pickup, plenty of clearly marked bins, and meaningful fines for repeat offenders—along with educational campaigns in schools and community centers to build a culture of respect for shared spaces. I’d also like to see programs that pay local artists to design creative signage and murals about keeping our streets clean, so the message feels positive, visible, and part of the neighborhood’s identity.

statements.statement: As someone who spends a lot of time in parks and playgrounds with my young kids, I feel strongly that preventing littering is about both smart policy and shaping everyday habits. We need a mix of practical measures—plenty of clearly marked bins, consistent fines that are actually enforced, and well-maintained public spaces—alongside education campaigns in schools and communities that make caring for shared spaces a social norm. I’ve seen through my work that people are far more likely to do the right thing when it’s easy, visible, and feels like part of caring for others, not just following rules.

statements.statement: Spending so much time outdoors for work and with my family, it really gets to me how much trash ends up in our fields, ditches, and parks. The best way to cut down on littering is a mix of real consequences—fines that are actually enforced—and convenient options like plenty of well-placed bins and recycling stations. I’d also like to see more local education, especially for kids, about how litter harms wildlife, soil, and waterways, because once people understand that connection, they’re more likely to take responsibility.

statements.statement: As someone who’s spent a lifetime teaching and now volunteers in my community, I believe the best way to prevent littering is a mix of education and accountability. Clear signage, plenty of trash and recycling bins, and modest fines all help, but we also need to teach children and adults alike that caring for our shared spaces is a moral responsibility. Community clean-up days, school projects, and church initiatives can strengthen that sense of stewardship, so people see keeping parks and streets clean as part of respecting both God’s creation and one another.

statements.statement: I think the best way to stop littering is to make it really easy for people to throw things away properly, like having more trash and recycling bins in parks and on sidewalks. statements.statement: Working in outpatient care, I see every day how a clean, safe environment supports both physical and mental health, and I think our public spaces deserve the same standard. The best way to prevent littering is a mix of clear regulations with meaningful fines, abundant and well-maintained trash and recycling bins, and public education that starts in schools and is reinforced through community campaigns. I’d also support policies that make producers responsible for excess packaging and that fund local cleanup programs, because individuals shouldn’t shoulder all the blame for a waste system stacked against them.

statements.statement: At my age, having seen cities on both sides of the Atlantic change over the decades, I’m convinced that preventing littering starts with strong public services and shared responsibility: plenty of bins, frequent street cleaning, and clear, consistently enforced fines for those who still toss rubbish on the ground. Just as important, though, is community education and engagement—bringing schools, local groups, and volunteers together to teach respect for our shared spaces, much like we care for a patient or a home kitchen, so everyone feels proud enough of their neighborhood not to leave it in a state.

statements.statement: I think the best way to prevent littering is to have more trash and recycling bins in places where people actually hang out, like parks, bus stops, and near schools, so it’s easy to do the right thing. There should also be clear signs and real consequences, like fines or community service, for people who still litter, because it’s not fair to everyone else who wants clean streets and nature. Schools and churches could help teach kids early on why taking care of the environment matters, so it becomes a habit instead of just a rule.
